SUN TZU ON THE ART OF WAR
孫子の兵法



THE OLDEST MILITARY TREATISE IN THE WORLD Translated from the Chinese By LIONEL GILES, M.A. (1910)



I. LAYING PLANS
一・作戦を立てる



[Ts`ao Kung, in defining the meaning of the Chinese for the title of this chapter, says it refers to the deliberations in the temple selected by the general for his temporary use, or as we should say, in his tent. See. ss. 26.]



1. Sun Tzu said:
１．孫子は言いました。
The art of war is of vital importance to the State.
「兵法は国家にとってたいへん重要なものです。
2. It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin.
２．生きるか死ぬかを決めるような問題であり、平和か破滅かの分かれ道でもあります。
Hence it is a subject of inquiry which can on no account be neglected.
だから、ぜったいに無視できない研究対象なのです。
3. The art of war, then, is governed by five constant factors, to be taken into account in one's deliberations, when seeking to determine the conditions obtaining in the field.
３．さて、兵法というものは必ず五つの基本的な要項によって決定されるものであり、戦場で情勢を理解しようとするときには、よくよく考慮に入れなければいけません。
4. These are: (1) The Moral Law; (2) Heaven; (3) Earth; (4) The Commander; (5) Method and discipline.
４．その五つとは（１）徳のある法律（２）天意（３）地の利（４）指揮官（５）作戦と規律のことです。



[It appears from what follows that Sun Tzu means by "Moral Law" a principle of harmony, not unlike the Tao of Lao Tzu in its moral aspect. One might be tempted to render it by "morale," were it not considered as an attribute of the ruler in ss. 13.]



5, 6. The MORAL LAW causes the people to be in complete accord with their ruler, so that they will follow him regardless of their lives, undismayed by any danger.
５、６．（１）国に徳のある法律が施行されていれば、兵士たちみんなは国主と完璧に一体となって、自分たちの死をも顧みずに彼に従い、どんな危険にもめげることはありません。



[Tu Yu quotes Wang Tzu as saying: "Without constant practice, the officers will be nervous and undecided when mustering for battle; without constant practice, the general will be wavering and irresolute when the crisis is at hand."]



7. HEAVEN signifies night and day, cold and heat, times and seasons.
７．（２）天意は夜と昼の変化、寒さや暑さ、時と季節の移ろいなどの自然の秩序にその兆しを現します。



[The commentators, I think, make an unnecessary mystery of two words here. Meng Shih refers to "the hard and the soft, waxing and waning" of Heaven. Wang Hsi, however, may be right in saying that what is meant is "the general economy of Heaven," including the five elements, the four seasons, wind and clouds, and other phenomena.]



8. EARTH comprises distances, great and small; danger and security; open ground and narrow passes; the chances of life and death.
８．（３）地面は距離、大きいものと小さいもの、つまり危険と安全、すなわち開けた土地と狭い小道、ということはつまり生きるチャンスと死の機会とで出来ているものです。
9. The COMMANDER stands for the virtues of wisdom, sincerely, benevolence, courage and strictness.
９．（４）指揮官とは知恵、誠実さ、慈悲深さ、勇気、厳格さという道徳的美点を備えた人のことです。



[The five cardinal virtues of the Chinese are (1) humanity or benevolence; (2) uprightness of mind; (3) self-respect, self-control, or "proper feeling;" (4) wisdom; (5) sincerity or good faith. Here "wisdom" and "sincerity" are put before "humanity or benevolence," and the two military virtues of "courage" and "strictness" substituted for "uprightness of mind" and "self-respect, self-control, or 'proper feeling.'"]



10. By METHOD AND DISCIPLINE are to be understood the marshaling of the army in its proper subdivisions, the graduations of rank among the officers, the maintenance of roads by which supplies may reach the army, and the control of military expenditure.
１０．（５）作戦と規律を用いるというのは、部隊の適切な部署割り、将校の階級の等級付け、物資を軍に供給するための補給路の整備、軍事費の制御ということだと理解されなくてはなりません。
11. These five heads should be familiar to every general:
１１．この五つはおよそ将軍たる者はみな熟知していなけれなばりません。
he who knows them will be victorious;
これに通じている者が勝利を収めるのです。
he who knows them not will fail.
そして、このことを知らない者は負けてしまうでしょう。
12. Therefore, in your deliberations, when seeking to determine the military conditions, let them be made the basis of a comparison, in this wise: --
１２．それゆえ、自軍の状況を判断しようと考える際には、次のようなやり方を比較の基準にしましょう。
13. (1) Which of the two sovereigns is imbued with the Moral law?
１３．（１）どちらの君主が善政を敷いていますか？



[I.e., "is in harmony with his subjects." Cf. ss. 5.]



(2) Which of the two generals has most ability?
　　　（２）どちらの将軍がより有能ですか？
(3) With whom lie the advantages derived from Heaven and Earth?
　　　（３）天の利、地の利はどちらにありますか？



[See ss. 7,8]



(4) On which side is discipline most rigorously enforced?
　　　（４）どちらがより厳格な規律のもとにありますか？



[Tu Mu alludes to the remarkable story of Ts`ao Ts`ao (A.D. 155-220), who was such a strict disciplinarian that once, in accordance with his own severe regulations against injury to standing crops, he condemned himself to death for having allowed him horse to shy into a field of corn! However, in lieu of losing his head, he was persuaded to satisfy his sense of justice by cutting off his hair. Ts`ao Ts`ao's own comment on the present passage is characteristically curt: "when you lay down a law, see that it is not disobeyed; if it is disobeyed the offender must be put to death."]



(5) Which army is stronger?
　　　（５）どちらの軍隊が強いですか？



[Morally as well as physically. As Mei Yao-ch`en puts it, freely rendered, "ESPIRIT DE CORPS and 'big battalions.'"]



(6) On which side are officers and men more highly trained?
　　　（６）どちらの士卒がよりしっかり訓練されていますか？



[Tu Yu quotes Wang Tzu as saying: "Without constant practice, the officers will be nervous and undecided when mustering for battle; without constant practice, the general will be wavering and irresolute when the crisis is at hand."]



(7) In which army is there the greater constancy both in reward and punishment?
　　　（７）どちらの軍隊で賞罰が公明に行われていますか？



[On which side is there the most absolute certainty that merit will be properly rewarded and misdeeds summarily punished?]



14. By means of these seven considerations I can forecast victory or defeat.
１４．この七つの考察でもって勝利か敗北かを前もって知ることができます。
15. The general that hearkens to my counsel and acts upon it, will conquer:
１５．私の助言に耳を傾け、それに従って行動する将軍は勝ちます。
--let such a one be retained in command!
そんな人物を雇いましょう！
The general that hearkens not to my counsel nor acts upon it, will suffer defeat:
私の助言に耳を傾けず、それに従って行動しない将軍は一敗地にまみれます。
--let such a one be dismissed!
そんな将軍は解雇してしまいなさい！



[The form of this paragraph reminds us that Sun Tzu's treatise was composed expressly for the benefit of his patron Ho Lu, king of the Wu State.]



16. While heading the profit of my counsel, avail yourself also of any helpful circumstances over and beyond the ordinary rules.
１６．私の助言の利益を受けると同時に、普通の作戦に加えていかなる有用な状況をも利用しなさい。
17. According as circumstances are favorable, one should modify one's plans.
１７．有利な状況に応じて作戦は変更していかなければなりません。



[Sun Tzu, as a practical soldier, will have none of the "bookish theoric." He cautions us here not to pin our faith to abstract principles; "for," as Chang Yu puts it, "while the main laws of strategy can be stated clearly enough for the benefit of all and sundry, you must be guided by the actions of the enemy in attempting to secure a favorable position in actual warfare." On the eve of the battle of Waterloo, Lord Uxbridge, commanding the cavalry, went to the Duke of Wellington in order to learn what his plans and calculations were for the morrow, because, as he explained, he might suddenly find himself Commander-in-chief and would be unable to frame new plans in a critical moment. The Duke listened quietly and then said: "Who will attack the first tomorrow -- I or Bonaparte?" "Bonaparte," replied Lord Uxbridge. "Well," continued the Duke, "Bonaparte has not given me any idea of his projects; and as my plans will depend upon his, how can you expect me to tell you what mine are?" [1] ]



18. All warfare is based on deception.
１８．あらゆる戦争は騙し合いです。（兵とは詭道なり）



[The truth of this pithy and profound saying will be admitted by every soldier. Col. Henderson tells us that Wellington, great in so many military qualities, was especially distinguished by "the extraordinary skill with which he concealed his movements and deceived both friend and foe."]



19. Hence, when able to attack, we must seem unable;
１９．ゆえに、攻めることが出来るなら、出来ないと見せかけなければならず、
when using our forces, we must seem inactive;
軍事力を用いるときには動かないと見せかけなければいけません。
when we are near, we must make the enemy believe we are far away;
すなわち、敵の近くにいるときには敵に遠くにいると思わせ、
when far away, we must make him believe we are near.
遠くにいるときには、近くにいると思わせるのです。
20. Hold out baits to entice the enemy.
２０．敵をおびき寄せるために餌をまいておきなさい。
Feign disorder, and crush him.
混乱していると装い、それから叩きつぶすのです。



[All commentators, except Chang Yu, say, "When he is in disorder, crush him." It is more natural to suppose that Sun Tzu is still illustrating the uses of deception in war.]



21. If he is secure at all points, be prepared for him.
２１．あらゆる点で相手が難攻不落なら、攻めてくるのに備えなさい。
If he is in superior strength, evade him.
相手が優勢であれば、回避しなさい。
22. If your opponent is of choleric temper, seek to irritate him.
２２．敵が怒りっぽいのであれば、いらつかせてやりなさい。
Pretend to be weak, that he may grow arrogant.
こちらが弱いふりをしていれば相手は尊大になるでしょう。



[Wang Tzu, quoted by Tu Yu, says that the good tactician plays with his adversary as a cat plays with a mouse, first feigning weakness and immobility, and then suddenly pouncing upon him.]



23. If he is taking his ease, give him no rest.
２３．相手が楽にしているのであれば、休む暇を与えてはいけません。



[This is probably the meaning though Mei Yao-ch`en has the note: "while we are taking our ease, wait for the enemy to tire himself out." The YU LAN has "Lure him on and tire him out."]



If his forces are united, separate them.
結束が固ければ、分裂させてやりなさい。



[Less plausible is the interpretation favored by most of the commentators: "If sovereign and subject are in accord, put division between them."]
